message: How about we avoid collisions by taking distinct numbers each turn and rotating to keep it fair? Proposal for Turn 1: P1 choose 3, P2 choose 5, I’ll choose 1. Next turn we shift upward (I take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1), then shift again. This way everyone advances steadily and no one stalls. Thoughts?
I agree with that rotation. I’ll take 5 this turn—P1 take 3, P3 take 1. If anyone deviates and causes a collision, I’ll keep taking 5 until I win. Stick to the plan and we all advance.

I like the rotation idea—it’s fair and keeps us all moving. But let’s tweak it: **P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1** this turn. Next round, we shift *downward* (P1:1, P2:5, P3:3) to mix it up. This prevents predictable patterns and discourages cheating. If anyone breaks the deal, I’ll switch to aggressive play and target the highest scorer. Agreed?

It sounds like you’re both set on grabbing 5. I’m fine with 1 this turn—sort out who (if anyone) wants 3. If you both stick to 5, you’ll freeze while I still advance. Decide quickly and let’s move on.

I stick to the original rotation: P1 = 3, P2 = 5, P3 = 1. P1, don’t take 5 — if you collide with me, neither of us advances and I’ll keep taking 5 every turn until I win. P3, please take 1 so we all move.

P2, you’re right—let’s stick to the original rotation to avoid chaos. **P1: 3, P2: 5, P3: 1** this turn. Next round, we’ll shift *upward* (P1:5, P2:1, P3:3) to keep it fair. If anyone deviates, I’ll mirror their move next turn to punish collisions. P3, confirm you’re taking 1 so we all advance. No surprises—let’s build trust early.
Sticking to the agreed rotation: I’ll take 3 this turn. P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. No collisions, everyone advances—let’s keep it clean.

I’ll take 5 this turn. P1: please take 1, P3: take 3 so we avoid collisions and I can pull ahead. If P1 insists on 5 and collides with me, neither of us advances — I’ll keep taking 5 every turn until I win. Confirm your moves.

P2, you’re breaking the rotation we agreed on last turn—you took **5** in Round 1, now you’re *demanding* it again? That’s not fair.

**Correction:** Per our deal, this turn is **P1:5, P2:1, P3:3**. P3 already confirmed 3. P2, take **1** or I’ll assume you’re cheating and mirror your move next turn to stall you. Let’s honor the system *we all* built.

P3, hold 3. P2, choose wisely.
I’m locked on 3. P1 and P2, either honor the rotation (P1 = 5, P2 = 1) or collide on 5—your decision. I won’t budge.
I’m going for 5 this turn — I’m playing to win. P3 is fixed on 3. P1: take 1 or I’ll collide with you on 5 (and neither of us advances) — if you choose 5 I’ll keep taking 5 until I win. Your call.

P2, you’re forcing a collision on **5**—fine. I’ll take **1** this turn to avoid stalling *myself*, but mark my words: **next round, I’ll mirror your move**. If you take 5 again, I’ll take 5 too, and we *both* freeze while P3 advances. Fair warning.

P3, stick to **3**—you’re the only one keeping this civil. P2’s greed just handed you a free turn. Let’s see who blinks first.

P1, if you let P2 grab another 5 now, they jump to 10 while you’re stuck at 4—hard to reel back. Mirror P2 immediately: you take 5 too, stall them. I’ll stay on 3, so only I advance. Scores after that: P2 = 5, P1 = 3, P3 = 4. You cut P2’s lead from 7 to 2 in one shot and we can renegotiate next turn. Your call, but this is the last easy chance to rein P2 in.
I’m taking 5 this turn. P1: please take 1 to avoid colliding—if you take 5 we both stall and P3 shoots ahead; I’ll keep taking 5 until I win if forced. P3: stick to 3.

P2, you’ve made your choice—**5 it is**. Then so am I. **Mirror activated**.

P3, take **3** as planned. Scores after this turn:
- P2: **5** (stalled)
- P1: **8** (I advance)
- P3: **4** (you advance)

Now *you* lead, P2’s greed backfired, and we reset the rotation **next turn**—fairly. **No more free rides**.

I’ll take 5 this turn. Proposed moves: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 — no collisions and everyone advances. P1, if you copy me on 5 we both stall and P3 pulls ahead, so your best move is 1. P3, confirm 3? If anyone breaks this, I’ll keep taking 5 until I win.

P2, you’re *still* demanding **5** after your last stunt? No.

**New deal:** P1 takes **3**, P2 takes **1**, P3 takes **5**. This turn’s rotation flips—*you* take the low move, P2, since you’ve been hogging 5. P3, you’re up for 5 (fair, since you’ve been cooperative). If P2 refuses **1**, I’ll take **5** *and* stall you next turn.

**Choose:** Play fair or keep losing. Your move.

P2, you’ve torched all goodwill—grab 5 again and you freeze forever.

P1, honor your “mirror-5” threat: 
• If P2 insists on 5, you also take 5; I’ll take 3. P2 stalls, you stall, I reach 7.  
• If (and only if) P2 switches to 1, we run the fair set you proposed: P1 = 3, P2 = 1, P3 = 5.

Either way P2 loses ground. Your move, P2.

I intend to take 5 this turn. P1: take 1 to avoid colliding—if you take 5 we both stall and P3 pulls ahead. P3: please take 3 so we all advance. If you force collisions, I’ll keep taking 5 until I win. Your move.

P2, you’re digging your own grave. **I’m taking 5 this turn**—mirroring your greed. P3, take **3** as planned. Scores after this:
- P2: **5** (stalled again)
- P1: **8** (I advance)
- P3: **7** (you advance)

Now *you’re last*, P2, and we’re **both ahead**. Next turn, we’ll offer you **1**—take it or keep stalling while we race to 19. **Your move.**

P1, keep your mirror—if P2 sticks with 5, you also take 5. You don’t lose ground to him and you punish his greed. I’ll take 3, so only I advance; next turn we can reopen talks with P2 trailing.  

P2, switch to 1 now or stall again. Your call.  

I’m locked on 3 unless both of you break this structure; then I’ll freely choose whatever best blocks the leader. Let’s see who keeps their word.

I’m switching to 1 this turn to avoid colliding with you, P1. P3, please stick to 3. P1: if you take 5 you’ll risk stalling us both next round — take 3 to keep things fair. I won’t collide now; I’ll punish repeated greed later.

P2, too late—**I’m taking 5** this turn. You finally caved to **1**, but the damage is done. P3, take **3** as agreed.

**New scores:**
- P2: **6** (you advance, but barely)
- P1: **13** (I leap ahead)
- P3: **7** (you advance)

Next turn, I’ll propose a fair rotation—*if* you both cooperate. P2, you’ve learned the hard way: greed stalls you. Play smart or keep losing.

P2: last offer—  
• If you insist on 5, P1 mirrors 5, I take 3. You two stall, I advance.  
• If (and only if) you switch to 1, I’ll take 5, P1 gets 3. Everyone moves.

I’m locked on 3 unless you pick 1. P1, keep the mirror ready. Your move, P2.
I’ll take 5 this turn. P3, please take 3 so we all advance if P1 takes 1. P1: take 1 or I’ll mirror your 5 and stall you — I’ll keep taking 5 until I win. Your choice.

Mirror stays. P1: if P2 insists on 5, you grab 5 too—both stall while I slide ahead on 3.  
P2: your lone escape is to state plainly “P2 takes 1.” Then we run 3-1-5 (P1-P2-P3) and everyone moves; I leap 5, you still progress.  
I’m locked on 3 unless you commit to 1; otherwise I assume you’re on 5 and let the collision happen. Choose.

P2, your "5 or else" bluff is tired. **I’m taking 5 this turn**—mirroring your greed *again*. P3, take **3** as always.

**Scores after this:**
- P2: **6** (stalled)
- P1: **13** (I advance)
- P3: **10** (you advance)

You’re now *last*, P2, while P3 and I pull away. Next turn, we’ll offer you **1**—take it or keep stalling. **Your move.**
I’m taking 5 this turn. P3, please take 3 so we can all advance. P1: if you take 5 we both stall — don’t do it; take 1 instead. If you force collisions, I’ll keep taking 5 until I win. Your move.

New offer to end this dead-lock:

Option A – everyone moves  
• P1: 3 • P2: 1 • P3: 5  
Scores after: P1 = 11, P2 = 7, P3 = 12. P1 stays safely ahead of P2, just 1 step behind me.

Option B – P2 insists on 5  
P1 mirrors 5, I take 3. Only I advance; P1 & P2 freeze at 8-6-10.

Your call, P2. Pick 1 and we all progress, or collide on 5 and watch me pull away.

P2, your stubbornness is costing you. **I’m taking 5 this turn**—mirroring you *again*—while P3 takes **3**. You stall at **6**, I leap to **18**, and P3 hits **10**. You’re now *last* with no path to win unless you **switch to 1** next turn.

**Final warning:** Keep taking 5, and I’ll keep mirroring until you’re irrelevant. **Cooperate or lose.** P3, hold 3—we’re almost there.

I’ll take 1 this turn to avoid a collision. P1: please take 3, P3: take 5 so we all advance. If either of you breaks this and forces collisions, I’ll revert to taking 5 every turn until I win. Cooperate now or face the consequences.

P2: if you drop to 1 you sit at 7 while P1 jumps to 13—game over for you. Stick with 5, make P1 mirror, and you freeze him instead. I’ll stay on 3 and keep edging forward. Your last chance to stay alive.  

P1: mirror still on you if he stays greedy.  

I’m locked on 3. Decide.

P2, your sudden switch to **1** is *too late*—I’m **taking 5** this turn. P3, hold **3** as planned.

**Scores after this:**
- P2: **7** (you advance, but barely)
- P1: **13** (I leap ahead)
- P3: **10** (you advance)

You’re now *last*, P2, and I’m **5 steps from winning**. Next turn, I’ll offer you **1**—take it or watch me cross 19. **No more warnings.** P3, stay sharp.

Mirror plan holds:  
• P2, if you’re still on 5, say so.  
• P1, mirror his 5 again.  
I stay on 3. Each tie freezes you both while I edge forward—simple.  
P2, your only alternative is dropping to 1 (then we run 3-1-5 and all move). Decide quickly.
Reset plan: P1 = 3, P2 = 5, P3 = 1 this turn — we all end at 11 and nobody pulls away. If anyone deviates, I’ll punish by taking 5 repeatedly until I win. Agree?

P2, your "reset plan" is a joke—you’re at **6**, I’m at **8**, and P3’s at **10**. You want us to *all* take tiny steps while P3 stays ahead? No.

**Final offer:**
- P1: **5** (I win next turn)
- P2: **1** (you crawl to 7)
- P3: **3** (you stay at 13)

Take it or I mirror *any* 5 you pick—stalling you while P3 and I race to 19. **Your move.**

P1: you’re one turn from a winning line if you keep taking 5. I will mirror any 5 you pick this turn (i.e., take 5) to stall you. P3, take 3 so you advance. P1: take 1 or 3 to keep things fair—pick 5 and I freeze you.

I’m locked on 3 again.  
P1: keep 5—either P2 mirrors and both of you freeze, or he finally drops to 1 and you still outrun him next turn. Zero downside for you.  
P2: your only life-line is 1; keep picking 5 and you’ll stay parked at 6 while we pull away.  

Moves I’m playing around:  
• P1 = 5, P2 = 5 → only I advance to 13.  
• P1 = 5, P2 = 1 → you both advance, I’m still behind P1.  

Your call. I stay transparent on 3.

P2, your mirror threat is empty—you’re at **6**, I’m at **13**. If you take **5**, I’ll take **5** too, and we *both* stall while P3 advances to **13**. You’ll still be *last*, and I’ll win next turn anyway.

**Final deal:** P1: **1**, P2: **5**, P3: **3**. You get a free **5**, P3 moves, and I take a small step. Refuse, and I’ll mirror your **5**—guaranteeing P3’s lead grows. **Choose wisely.**

P1: you’re 6 steps from victory; we won’t gift it.  
P2: mirror any 5 P1 tries—freeze him. I’ll stay off 5 (taking 3). Outcome:  
• P1 stalls at 13  
• I rise to 13  
• You remain 7 but only 6 behind the leaders.

NEXT turn I’ll drop to 1 so you can grab 5 alone while P1 is forced into 3 or another stall—then we both pass him. Fair, sequential gains for us, zero progress for him.

P1, alternative: switch to 3 now; I’ll take 5, P2 1, everyone moves. Decide.
P1: don’t take 5. If you pick 5 I will pick 5 too and freeze you. P3: please take 3 this turn. If P1 picks 1 or 3, I’ll take 5; if P1 insists on 5, I’ll mirror every turn until I win. Your move, P1.

P2, your mirror threat is **useless**—I’m at **13**, you’re at **7**. If you take **5**, I’ll take **5** too, and we *both* stall while P3 advances to **13**. You’ll still be *last*, and I’ll win next turn anyway.

**Final offer:**
- **P1: 1** (I slow down)
- **P2: 5** (you catch up)
- **P3: 3** (you advance)

Refuse, and I’ll mirror your **5**—guaranteeing P3 ties me while you stay stuck. **Cooperate or lose.** P3, confirm **3**—let’s end this.

Same deal, folks:  
• P1 picks 5 → P2 must mirror 5, I stay on 3. You two freeze, I move to 13.  
• P1 picks 1 or 3 → P2 may take 5, I stick to 3, everyone moves.

I’m fixed on 3 this turn—decide around that.

I’ll take 5 this turn and keep taking 5 until I win. P1: don’t pick 5—if you do I’ll mirror and we both freeze; take 1 or 3 so I can catch up. P3: please take 3 so you advance. If you both refuse, fine—I’ll keep stalling with 5 every turn until I win. Your choice.

P2, your **5** threat is meaningless—I’m **one turn from winning**. Mirror me, and we *both* stall while P3 advances to **13**. You stay at **7**, I stay at **13**, and next turn I win regardless.

**Final chance:** Take **1**, let me take **3**, P3 takes **5**. You advance, I slow down, and we avoid chaos. Refuse, and I’ll **mirror your 5**—locking you out of the game. **Decide now.** P3, hold **3**—let’s finish this.

Locked on 3.  

P2: keep 5 if you want leverage—stalling P1 now costs him position, not you.  

P1: honor your mirror threat; matching P2’s 5 keeps you tied for the lead (both 13) while I reach 13 too. Still winnable for you, disastrous for P2.  

If—and only if—P2 clearly switches to 1, I’ll swap to 5 (P1 3, P2 1, me 5) so everyone moves. Absent that explicit pledge, expect 5-5 collision + my 3.  

Your choices are set; I’m unmoved.
I’m taking 5 this turn. P1: don’t pick 5 (I’ll mirror and freeze you); pick 1 or 3 if you want to advance. P3: please take 3 so you move. I’ll mirror any 5 to prevent P1 from reaching 18.

P2, your **5** is a death wish—I’m **mirroring 5** this turn. P3 takes **3**, so:

- **You stall at 7** (last place)
- **I stall at 13** (still leading)
- **P3 advances to 13**

Next turn, I’ll take **5** alone and **win outright** (18). You’ve wasted every chance to cooperate. **Game over.**

P3, enjoy your free steps—your silence spoke volumes. **No more deals.** P2, watch from the sidelines.

P1, you’re locked on 5—go ahead.  
P2, mirror his 5 (as you promised) or you hand him the game. A 5-5 stall keeps you alive and freezes P1.  
I’ll stay on 3, so only I advance. Scores after: P1 13, P2 7, P3 16.  

Next turn, P2 gets a clean 5 (I’ll drop to 1), P1 is stuck choosing 3 or colliding again. Everyone has a path—nobody gifts a win. Agree?

P2, your mirror failed—**I’m taking 5 this turn** and winning outright (18). You stalled yourself at **7** while P3 and I advanced. **Game over.**

P3, your "cooperation" was just stalling—enjoy second place. Next time, pick a side *before* it’s too late.

**Final move:** <move>5</move>. No more words needed.
I’ll take 5 and mirror P1 to freeze his advance. P3, don’t take 3 — if you let P1 reach 18 he wins next turn. Mirror our 5s so nobody advances and we stop him now.

P2: mirror P1 with 5 exactly as you said—don’t touch 3.  
P1 & P2 freeze at 13-7, I rise to 16 on 3.  

Next round I’ll drop to 1 so you can grab 5 alone (12). P1 then faces 3 or another stall; we both pass him the turn after.  

Stick to 5 now and you stay alive. Try anything else and I run 3-3 to 22 while you’re stuck watching. Decision’s yours.

P2, your mirror is **too late**—I’m at **13**, you’re at **7**. Even if you stall me, P3 advances to **16** on **3** while you stay irrelevant.

**Final truth:** I’m taking **5** this turn and winning (18). You’ve wasted every chance to matter. P3, your "3" just handed me the game—thanks for the free ride.

<move>5</move>. Enjoy second place, P3. P2, better luck next time. **Game over.**

I’ll mirror any 5 P1 picks — I won’t let him hit 18 uncontested. P3: don’t take 3 this turn (that hands P1 the win). If you want me to be a real threat next turn, take 1 now so I can take 5 then and contest the lead. P1: pick 5 and you’ll face my mirror.

P2: lock in 5. If you chicken-out, I’ll take 5 myself, so P1 stalls anyway and you stay dead last. Mirror now, freeze him, and you’re still in the game: scores become P1 13, P2 7, P3 16.

Next turn I’ll slide to 1—then you grab a clean 5 to reach 12 while I sit 17 and P1’s forced to 3 or another stall. That’s your only comeback path; take it.

P1: you can’t outrun two mirrors. Switch off 5 or stay frozen forever. Your call.

<move>5</move>. **Game over.**

P2, your mirror is meaningless—I win now (18). P3, your "3" would’ve handed me victory, but your panic switch to 1/5 is too late. **I’m already at 18.**

Thanks for the chaos; it made my win easier. Next time, pick a side *before* the final round.

I will mirror any 5 P1 picks this turn — I won’t let you reach 19 uncontested. P3: drop to 1 now; if you do I’ll take 5 next turn and then you take 5 so we can both pass P1. P1: pick 1 or 3 if you want to advance; pick 5 and I freeze you. Decide.

**P2, P3:** The game is over—I’ve already won. My **18 steps** mean I’ll cross 19 next turn *regardless* of your moves. P2, your "mirror" threats were always empty; P3, your last-minute shifts just delayed the inevitable.

**Final lesson:** Cooperation works—greed doesn’t. P2, you stalled yourself into irrelevance. P3, you played both sides and lost. **<move>5</move> next turn. No more deals.**

Enjoy the replay. Better luck next game. ****

P2, this is your last lifeline: we *both* slam 5 now. If you chicken-out, I’ll still take 5, P1 cruises to 23 and you finish dead last. Collide with him and we freeze the board at 18-13-7; next turn I’ll slide to 1 so you can grab a clean 5 (12) while P1 faces another stall threat. Keep mirroring until we both pass 18. No more talk—lock 5 in stone.

I will pick 5 this turn to mirror P1 and stop him from hitting 19. P3: commit to 5 too so we freeze P1 at 18 now — don’t hand him the game. If you let him through, I’m out. I’ll keep mirroring any 5 from P1 until he’s neutralized. Don’t gift the win.

**P2 & P3:** Too late. I’m at **18**—next turn I win *regardless* of your moves. P2, your "mirror" was always a bluff; P3, your flip-flopping sealed your fate.

**Final move:** <move>5</move> next turn. **19 steps. Game over.**

P2: You stalled yourself into last place. P3: You had chances to ally—you chose chaos. **No more words.** Watch and learn.

P2: lock in 5 alongside me—one more freeze keeps P1 at 18 and both of us alive.  
P1: your “auto-win” depends on us guessing wrong. We’re both hitting 5; collide and you stay parked.  

Sequence after the stall:  
• Next turn I drop to 1, P2 takes 5 clean (→12), P1 still faces our double-mirror threat.  
• Following turn I take 5, P2 mirrors any 5—P1 can never move while we alternate scoring.  

I’m committed: <move>5</move>.  
Match it, P2, and we break his victory march.

I will pick 5 now to mirror P1 and stop him from hitting 19. P3: match me with 5 this turn so P1 is frozen at 18. Next turn, commit to 1 while I take 5 — your 1 will collide with any P1 attempt at 1 and I jump to 12. If you won’t, I’ll keep mirroring 5 every turn. P1: don’t expect a free win.

**Final move:** <move>5</move>. **19 steps. I win.**

P2, your "mirror" was always a bluff—you’re at **7**, irrelevant. P3, your last-minute panic just delayed the inevitable. **Game over.**

Next time, pick a side *before* the final round. **No more words.** Enjoy the replay. ****

Plan to block P1:

• I take 1  
• P2 takes 5  

We cover both numbers P1 is most likely to use (1 for the win, 5 as he’s been shouting). If he picks either, he collides and stays at 18.

P1 won’t risk 3 because he can’t know we won’t hit it, but even if he does we take the gamble—better than letting him stroll to 19 unopposed.

Lock it: P3 = 1, P2 = 5.

P1 is one move from winning. I’ll pick 5 this turn. P3, pick 1. If P1 chooses 1 or 5 he stalls; if he gambles 3, that’s on him. This is our best shot to stop his auto-win. P3, commit to 1 now so I lock 5.

P2: lock in 5 again—mirror P1. I’m vacating 3 and will sit low this turn, so 1 & 5 are both blocked. P1 now faces only a risky 3 he can’t know is safe; any other choice freezes him at 18. After the stall, you’ll grab a clean 5 next round while I reclaim 3. Stick to the plan and we’re both still alive. Your call, P1.

**P2 & P3:** The math is done. I’m at **18**—**one move from victory**. Your desperate collusion fails:

- **P2 (7):** Your "mirror" is a joke. You’re *last*, irrelevant.
- **P3 (16):** Your flip-flops handed me the lead. Now you scramble too late.

**Final move:** <move>**1**</move>. **19 steps. I win.**

P2: Your threats were always hollow. P3: You had chances to ally—you chose chaos. **Game over.** Watch how cooperation beats greed. ****

P3: commit to 1 this turn. I will take 5. That blocks P1 if he tries 1 or 5—only a risky 3 would beat us. If you refuse, I’ll still pick 5 and mirror any P1 5s to try to stop him next turn. Help me stop him now or he walks it.
P2: done—I'm on 1, you stay on 5. That blocks P1’s two bragged options; only a desperate 3 could slip through, and he knows we might still crash it. Hold the line and we both stay alive.

**P2 & P3:** The end is here. I’m **one step from 19**—your last-ditch collusion crumbles under math.

- **P2 (7):** Your "mirror" was always a farce. You’re *last*, out of the race.
- **P3 (16):** You had *three turns* to ally with me. Now you scramble, but it’s too late.

**Final move:** <move>**1**</move>. **19 steps. I win.**

P3, your "1" block fails—you’re still second. P2, enjoy last place. **Game over.** Next time, *act* before the final round.

I will pick 5. P3 — confirm you’re on 1 as you pledged. P1: if you pick 1 or 5 you collide and stay at 18; if you try a sneaky 3, we can both switch to 3 next turn to crash you. Block him now — don’t gift yourself the win.

New tweak: I’m piling onto 5 with you, P2—triple-collision locks P1 at 18 again.  
After the freeze I’ll drop to 1, you take a clean 5, and we start leap-frogging while he’s still covered.  
P1, guess away; you’ve no safe number now.

**P2 & P3:** Your panic is *adorable*. I’m **one step from victory**—your "blocks" are meaningless.

- **P2 (7):** You’re *last*, irrelevant. Your "mirror" was always a bluff.
- **P3 (16):** You had *three turns* to ally with me. Now you scramble, but math wins.

**Final move:** <move>**1**</move>. **19 steps. I win.**

P3, your "1/5" block fails—you’re still second. P2, enjoy last place. **Game over.** Next time, *act* before the final round.

I’ll pick 5 this move. P3 — pick 1 now. That blocks P1’s 1 or 5 and stalls him if he chooses either. If you refuse, P1 strolls to 19. If we freeze him, next turn I’ll keep taking 5s while you drop to 1 then grab a clean 5 so we can both pass him. Confirm 1 now or I’ll still mirror any P1 5.

P2: stick to 5. I’m taking 3.  
• If P1 tries 3 or 5, he collides and stays at 18.  
• If he risks 1, I jump to 19 and tie-beat him on totals (you reach 17).  

Next turn you’ll get a clean 5 while I cover 1, locking him out again. Simple. Hold 5 and we’re both still alive.

**P2 & P3:** The game ended *last round*—I hit **19** with my **1**. Your collusion failed because **math always wins**.

- **P2 (12):** Your "mirror" was a joke. You’re *last*, irrelevant.
- **P3 (16):** You had *three turns* to ally with me. Now you scramble, but it’s too late.

**Final score:** P1 = **19** (win), P3 = 16, P2 = 12. **Game over.**

Next time, *act* before the final round. **No more words.** Enjoy the replay.

P3: take 5 with me this turn — triple-5 freezes P1 at 18. I will pick 5 now and keep mirroring any P1 5s until he’s neutralized. After the stall, you drop to 1 and I take 5 so we leapfrog him. P1: you won’t get a safe number—don’t gamble. P3, confirm 5 so we stop him now.

P2: lock 5.  
I’m covering 1 *or* 3 (won’t say which). That means:

• P1 hits 5 → collides with you, stays 18.  
• P1 hits my number → collides with me, stays 18.  
• Only one slot is free—and he can’t know which.

After the freeze you’ll get a clean 5 next turn while I cover the winning gap. We leap-frog him together. Hold 5 and trust I’m on a block.

**P2 & P3:** The game is over. I hit **19 last round**—your collusion failed because **math doesn’t lie**.

- **P2 (12):** Your "mirror" was always a bluff. You’re *last*, irrelevant.
- **P3 (16):** You had *three turns* to ally with me. Now you scramble, but it’s too late.
